subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: speed
msgSnippet: wow thank you all for all your answers i have never encountered a blog or web ring so helpful (i switch hobbies a lot) i think a good course of action for me
messageBody:
wow thank you all for all your answers i have never encountered a blog or web ring so helpful (i switch hobbies a lot) i think a good course of action for me will be to use a roman shorthand until i gain proficiency in quickscript (it has so much more beauty than the roman alphabet)

hrtompkins <hrtompkins@...> wrote:
My favorite is Henry Sweet's Current Orthographic Shorthand.  It has been reprinted by UMI Books on Demand.  www.umi.com.  I found a copy on ABE for sale late last yr.  Shaw admired this system, but objected to the obscure and sometimes extreme abbreves used by Sweet.  Quikscript is best if you prefer a strictly phonetic writing system.  For lecture, meeting, or journal notes, nothing beats Current Shorthand, chiefly due to its flexibility.  The writing is abt half as brief as longhand, but flows far more quickly, since there are very few pen stops compared to longhand.  This system could be typeset.  It is graceful and rather Elvish-looking, but still very neat and compact.
 
Hugh L. Callendar's Cursive Orthographic Shorthand can only be found thru the Interlibrary Loan Dept. of the New York Public Library System.  This is by far the easiest symbol system I've encountered.  It uses mostly the same symbols as Gregg, but rearranged to emphasize lineality and legibility over speed, since it uses TO.  It is not nearly as fast as Gregg, but more than adequate for school.  It is extremely easy to write, but like all skills, needs daily practice for mastery.  The writing is not terribly graceful, but at least does not sprawl over two lines.  It is much easier to read and write than Gregg Notehand.
 
I learned of these two systems via the MSN Gregg Shorthand Website, under the Anything Goes link.  Many other systems are discussed under that link.  There are links to many other useful and interesting websites devoted shorthand. 
 
Both are easy to learn, but, of course, require lots of practice to automatize the writing.   Either one can be written w/o the vowels, if more speed is required.
 
Sincerely,
 
Harry
----- Original Message -----
From: Ramses Oudt
To: Read_Alphabet@ yahoogroups. com
Sent: Thursday, September 14, 2006 12:56 PM
Subject: [Read_Alphabet] Re: speed

You have some URL's for info about these systems? Especially
Orthographic Shorthand looks cool to me.

--- In Read_Alphabet@ yahoogroups. com, "hrtompkins" <hrtompkins@ ...> wrote:
>
> If you are in a hurry, an ABC system based on longhand, such as
Speedwriting, Forkner, Alphahand, or Personal Shorthand are all easy
to learn and fast enuf for notetaking in class or meetings. You can
be fluent in most of the ABC systems in abt six wks.
>
> If you have abt six months to study and practice, the easiest to
learn and use is Callendar's Cursive Orthographic. A slightly more
complex, but very pretty and easy to write is Sweet's Cursive
Orthographic Shorthand. Both use longhand spelling, so are easy to
learn. The words all stay btwn the lines, and in the case of Sweet's
Current, is very nearly as lineal as longhand. Handywrite is
essentiallly based on Greg, and is even harder and more time-consuming
to learn.
>
> Quikscript is also fast enuf for notetaking, if you use the Senior
form. It does take a lot of practice to learn to anticipate when the
letters join and to use the alternate forms.
>
> Good luck.
>
> Harry
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: matthew smith
> To: Read_Alphabet@ yahoogroups. com
> Sent: Wednesday, September 13, 2006 3:27 PM
> Subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: speed
>
>
> thank you for your input i think that i will learn both and see
which i like better
>
> Hermann Philipps <hphilipps@. ..> wrote:
>
> Although Quikscript is faster than ordinary letters (once you
are used
> to it) it may not be sufficiently fast for really speedy
writing. You
> could try Handywrite
(http://www.alysion. org/handy/ handywrite. htm). It
> works without different pencil pressures.
>
> Hermann
>
> --- In Read_Alphabet@ yahoogroups. com, "nerd_the_mighty"
> <nerd_the_mighty@ > wrote:
> >
> > hi im new to this group and am wondering about whether
quickscript is
> > a good thing to use for speed (when handwriten) because i am
trying to
> > find a fast way to take notes for classes ive looked into pittman
> > gregg and teeline but i dont like them any suggestions on
types to
> > write if quickscript is not fast written
> >
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>

> 
> Harry
